Michael Schuerig wrote:
> On Wednesday 26 January 2005 03:46, ezra_epstein wrote:
>  > I did some work with .NET a while back.  The nUnit port was pretty
>  > cool: annotations, rather than naming conventions, are used to
>  > indicate test methods.
>  >
>  > I'm wondering, now that annotations have been added to Java, is
>  > anyone working on reverse-porting nUnit?  If so, I'm interested in
>  > helping. If not, anyone else interested in this?
> 
> I'm wondering, what is the advantage?

Well, Ruby and Smalltalk programmers can do neat things with tests that 
Java programmers can't do, because Ruby and Smalltalk don't require 
inheritance of any kind to do things like implement the Composite 
pattern. This opens the door for interesting uses of inheritance with 
test cases that Java doesn't allow (not supporting multiple 
implementation inheritance).

As to what those neat things are, I won't know until I try using such a 
thing in anger. My guess is that there are C# programmers out there who 
have a thing or two to teach us about tests and inheritance, since NUnit 
  works (more or less) like RUnit and SUnit do.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
